ABSTRACT
We present here a detailed calculation of opacities for Fe XVII at the physical conditions corresponding to the base of the
Solar convection zone. Many ingredients are involved in the calculation of opacities. We review the impact of each ingredient
on the final monochromatic and mean opacities (Rosseland and Planck). The necessary atomic data were calculated with the
ùëÖ-matrix and the distorted-wave (DW) methods. We study the effect of broadening, of resolution, of the extent of configuration
sets and of configuration interaction to understand the differences between several theoretical predictions as well as the existing
large disagreement with measurements. New Dirac ùëÖ-matrix calculations including all configurations up to the ùëõ = 4, 5 and
6 complexes have been performed as well as corresponding Breit‚ÄìPauli DW calculations. The DW calculations have been
extended to include autoionizing initial levels. A quantitative contrast is made between comparable DW and ùëÖ-matrix models.
We have reached self-convergence with ùëõ = 6 ùëÖ-matrix and DW calculations. Populations in autoionizing initial levels contribute
significantly to the opacities and should not be neglected. The ùëÖ-matrix and DW results are consistent under the similar treatment
of resonance broadening. The comparison with the experiment shows a persistent difference in the continuum while the filling
of the windows shows some improvement. The present study defines our path to the next generation of opacities and opacity
tables for stellar modeling.
